text:
26 Fulton Street, at the S.W. corner of Elizabeth Place, showing the building in which Hans Bergen carried on a bakery from 1717 to about 1730, in conjunction with a store, and a stable for horses of the residents of the Island when crossing to New York. The stable was a stone building, located, as near as can be ascertained, on the westerly corner of Fulton and Elizabeth Streets. A portion of the walls of which are supposed to form the easterly end of the building located there. In 1840, it was N. Guerneys' Mechanic's Hotel.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1) Fulton Street, at the N.W. corner of Elizabeth Place, showing, what in 1840 was, N. Guernsey's Mechanics Hall.
July 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) The same, another view.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3) The same, showing Elizabeth Place and the Fulton Street Elevated Lines of the B.M.T. on Fulton Street.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

A general view south from the Brooklyn Bridge at the East River, showing in the foreground, Fulton Street, between Elizabeth Place (left), and Columbia Heights. Note on Doughty Street, the Squibb and Son's buildings. Also shown is the Fulton Street Elevated Line.

June 4, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.
title: General view - Brooklyn - Brooklyn Bridge - East River.
